div.p: consisted of Bows & Arrows, Lances & Battle Axes, & Chields, (not but they had guns) they appeared like a small forest & would unwillingly bring to mind what is related of ancient times when our fore-fathers made War[.] At night we camped all on a leval plain where there was hardly a drop of water to be found[.] Many were the offers that Mr Henry got of horses which he would not accept, & even Mr Allen McDonell would not buy any of them notwithstanding the many truths I told them both – & Mr C. himself was even afraid that they would get better horses at the Shawyens than the one he was to get from the Borgne[.] Next morning we continued our march in the same regular form, but more gaudy with Paints & Feathers &c. & as we were approaching our destination the Shawyens were metting us, band succeeded band, till the whole of that nation joined our procession – & such a sight was not a small allurement to the curious eye, or to the mind fond of novelty. But Mr Henry's mind was too much allured by horses to cast his eye at large & catch the beauty of a splendid throng – tho he confessed that such two War-like nations he had never seen & that the sight was worthy of coming so far to see it[.] So many horses being gathered together & being trained to the chase & war, were so much animated that they might be said not to walk, but, to danced & pranced all the way[.] Their Riders, to shew their agility in managing a horse, pranked skiped & capered so much that their horses in a manner became unmanageable[.] What a field of temptation thus was to Mr Henry? & who could blame him for not being decisive in his choice?
